member.summary: Gets the kind of this symbol.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.TypeKind
member.summary: Gets the kind of this type.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.ContainingSymbol
member.summary: Get the symbol that logically contains this symbol.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.Locations
member.summary: Gets the locations where this symbol was originally defined, either in source or metadata. Some symbols (for example, partial classes) may be defined in more than one location.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.Arity
member.summary: Returns the arity of this type, or the number of type parameters it takes. A non-generic type has zero arity.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of this symbol. Symbols without a name return the empty string; null is never returned.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.TypeArguments
member.summary: Returns the type arguments that have been substituted for the type parameters. If nothing has been substituted for a give type parameters, then the type parameter itself is consider the type argument.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.TypeParameters
member.summary: Returns the type parameters that this type has. If this is a non-generic type, returns an empty ReadOnlyArray.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.ConstructedFrom
member.summary: Returns the type symbol that this type was constructed from. This type symbol has the same containing type (if any), but has type arguments that are the same as the type parameters (although its containing type might not).

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.DeclaredAccessibility
member.summary: Get this accessibility that was declared on this symbol. For symbols that do not have accessibility declared on them, returns NotApplicable.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.IsStatic
member.summary: Returns true if this symbol is "static"; i.e., declared with the "static" modifier or implicitly static.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.IsAbstract
member.summary: Returns true if this symbol was declared as requiring an override; i.e., declared with the "abstract" modifier. Also returns true on a type declared as "abstract", all interface types, and members of interface types.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.IsSealed
member.summary: Returns true if this symbol was declared to override a base class member and was also sealed from further overriding; i.e., declared with the "sealed" modifier. Also set for types that do not allow a derived class (declared with "sealed" or "static" or "struct" or "enum" or "delegate").

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.ErrorTypeSymbol.SpecialType
member.summary: Gets corresponding special TypeId of this type.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.MergedNamespaceSymbol
member.summary:
A MergedNamespaceSymbol represents a namespace that merges the contents of two or more other namespaces. Any sub-namespaces with the same names are also merged if they have two or more instances.
Merged namespaces are used to merged the symbols from multiple metadata modules and the source "module" into a single symbol tree that represents all the available symbols. The compiler resolves names against this merged set of symbols.
Typically there will not be very many merged namespaces in a Compilation: only the root namespaces and namespaces that are used in multiple referenced modules. (Microsoft, System, System.Xml, System.Diagnostics, System.Threading, ...)

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.MergedNamespaceSymbol.Create(Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.NamespaceExtent,Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.NamespaceSymbol,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.NamespaceSymbol},System.String)
member.summary: Create a possibly merged namespace symbol. If only a single namespace is passed it, it is just returned directly. If two or more namespaces are passed in, then a new merged namespace is created with the given extent and container.
member.param: The namespace extent to use, IF a merged namespace is created.
The containing namespace to used, IF a merged namespace is created.
One or more namespaces to merged. If just one, then it is returned. The merged namespace symbol may hold onto the array.
An optional name to give the resulting namespace.
member.returns: A namespace symbol representing the merged namespace.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.MergedNamespaceSymbol.SlowGetChildrenOfName(System.String)
member.summary: Method that is called from the CachingLookup to lookup the children of a given name. Looks in all the constituent namespaces.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.MergedNamespaceSymbol.SlowGetChildNames
member.summary: Method that is called from the CachingLookup to get all child names. Looks in all constituent namespaces.

member.summary: Initializes namespaces and types maps with information about namespaces and types immediately contained within this namespace.
member.param: The sequence of groups of TypeDef row ids for types contained within the namespace, recursively including those from nested namespaces. member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Metadata.PE.PEPropertySymbol.ExplicitInterfaceImplementations
member.summary:
Intended behavior: this property, P, explicitly implements an interface property, IP, if any of the following is true:
1) P.get explicitly implements IP.get and P.set explicitly implements IP.set 2) P.get explicitly implements IP.get and there is no IP.set 3) P.set explicitly implements IP.set and there is no IP.get
Extra or missing accessors will not result in errors, P will simply not report that it explicitly implements IP.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Retargeting.RetargetingAssemblySymbol
member.summary:
Essentially this is a wrapper around another AssemblySymbol that is responsible for retargeting symbols from one assembly to another. It can retarget symbols for multiple assemblies at the same time.
For example, compilation C1 references v1 of Lib.dll and compilation C2 references C1 and v2 of Lib.dll. In this case, in context of C2, all types from v1 of Lib.dll leaking through C1 (through method signatures, etc.) must be retargeted to the types from v2 of Lib.dll. This is what RetargetingAssemblySymbol is responsible for. In the example above, modules in C2 do not reference C1.m_AssemblySymbol, but reference a special RetargetingAssemblySymbol created for C1 by AssemblyManager.
Here is how retargeting is implemented in general: - Symbols from underlying assembly are substituted with retargeting symbols. - Symbols from referenced assemblies that can be reused as is (i.e. doesn't have to be retargeted) are used as is. - Symbols from referenced assemblies that must be retargeted are substituted with result of retargeting.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Retargeting.RetargetingAssemblySymbol.underlyingAssembly
member.summary: The underlying AssemblySymbol, it leaks symbols that should be retargeted. This cannot be an instance of RetargetingAssemblySymbol.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Retargeting.RetargetingAssemblySymbol.modules
member.summary: The list of contained ModuleSymbol objects. First item in the list is RetargetingModuleSymbol that wraps corresponding SourceModuleSymbol from underlyingAssembly.Modules list, the rest are PEModuleSymbols for added modules.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Retargeting.RetargetingAssemblySymbol.noPiaResolutionAssemblies
member.summary: An array of assemblies involved in canonical type resolution of NoPia local types defined within this assembly. In other words, all references used by a compilation referencing this assembly. The array and its content is provided by AssemblyManager and must not be modified.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Retargeting.RetargetingAssemblySymbol.linkedReferencedAssemblies
member.summary: An array of assemblies referenced by this assembly, which are linked (/l-ed) by each compilation that is using this AssemblySymbol as a reference. If this AssemblySymbol is linked too, it will be in this array too. The array and its content is provided by AssemblyManager and must not be modified.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Retargeting.RetargetingAssemblySymbol.NoPiaUnificationMap
member.summary: A map from a local NoPia type to corresponding canonical type.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Retargeting.RetargetingAssemblySymbol.isLinked
member.summary: Assembly is /l-ed by compilation that is using it as a reference.

Represents a primary module of a RetargetingAssemblySymbol. Essentially this is a wrapper around another SourceModuleSymbol that is responsible for retargeting symbols from one assembly to another. It can retarget symbols for multiple assemblies at the same time.
Here is how retargeting is implemented in general: - Symbols from underlying module are substituted with retargeting symbols. - Symbols from referenced assemblies that can be reused as is (i.e. don't have to be retargeted) are used as is. - Symbols from referenced assemblies that must be retargeted are substituted with result of retargeting.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.CSErrorTypeSymbol
member.summary: An error type, used to represent the type of a type binding operation when binding fails.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.CSErrorTypeSymbol.ExtractNonErrorType(Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.TypeSymbol)
member.summary:
If (we believe) we know which symbol the user intended, then we should retain that information in the corresponding error symbol - it can be useful for deciding how to handle the error. For example, we might want to know whether (we believe) the error type was supposed to be an interface, so that we can put it in a derived type's interface list, rather than in the base type slot.
Sometimes we will return the original definition of the intended symbol. For example, if we see IFoo<int> and we have an IFoo with a different arity or accessibility (e.g. IFoo<int> was constructed from an error symbol based on IFoo<T>), then we'll return IFoo<T>, rather than trying to construct a corresponding closed type (which may not be difficult/possible in the case of nested types or mismatched arities).
NOTE: Any non-null type symbol returned is guaranteed not to be an error type.
member.remarks: TypeSymbolExtensions.GetNonErrorGuess is a more discoverable version of this functionality. However, the real definition is in this class so that it can access the private field nonErrorGuessType.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.LookupFilter
member.summary: represents one-to-one symbol -> SingleLookupResult filter.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.LookupResult
member.summary:
A LookupResult summarizes the result of a name lookup within a scope It also allows combining name lookups from different scopes in an easy way.
A LookupResult can be ONE OF: empty - nothing found. a viable result - this kind of result prevents lookup into further scopes of lower priority. Viable results should be without error; ambiguity is handled in the caller. (Note that handling multiple "viable" results is not the same as in the VB compiler) a non-accessible result - this kind of result means that search continues into further scopes of lower priority for a viable result. An error is attached with the inaccessibility errors. Non-accessible results take priority over non-viable results. a non-viable result - a result that means that the search continues into further scopes of lower priority for a viable or non-accessible result. An error is attached with the error that indicates why the result is non-viable. A typical readon would be that it is the wrong kind of symbol.
Note that the class is poolable so its instances can be obtained from a pool vai GetInstance. Also it is a good idea to call Free on instances after they no longer needed.
The typical pattern is "caller allocates / caller frees" -
var result = LookupResult.GetInstance();
scope.Lookup(result, "foo"); ... use result ...
result.Clear(); anotherScope.Lookup(result, "moo"); ... use result ...
result.Free(); //result and its content is invalid after this
member.remarks:
Currently LookupResult is intended only for name lookup, not for overload resolution. It is not clear if overload resolution will work with the structure as is, require enhancements, or be best served by an alternate mechanism.
We might want to extend this to a more general priority scheme.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.ElasticCarriageReturnLineFeed
member.summary: An elastic trivia with kind EndOfLineTrivia containing both the carriage return and line feed characters. Elastic trivia are used to denote trivia that was not produced by parsing source text, and are usually not preserved during formatting.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.ElasticLineFeed
member.summary: An elastic trivia with kind EndOfLineTrivia containing a single line feed character. Elastic trivia are used to denote trivia that was not produced by parsing source text, and are usually not preserved during formatting.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.ElasticCarriageReturn
member.summary: An elastic trivia with kind EndOfLineTrivia containing a single carriage return character. Elastic trivia are used to denote trivia that was not produced by parsing source text, and are usually not preserved during formatting.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.ElasticSpace
member.summary: An elastic trivia with kind WhitespaceTrivia containing a single space character. Elastic trivia are used to denote trivia that was not produced by parsing source text, and are usually not preserved during formatting.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.ElasticTab
member.summary: An elastic trivia with kind WhitespaceTrivia containing a single tab character. Elastic trivia are used to denote trivia that was not produced by parsing source text, and are usually not preserved during formatting.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.ElasticMarker
member.summary: An elastic trivia with kind WhitespaceTrivia containing no characters. Elastic marker trivia are included automatically by factory methods when trivia is not specified. Syntax formatting will replace elastic markers with appropriate trivia.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.EndOfLine(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a trivia with kind EndOfLineTrivia containing the specified text.
member.param: The text of the trivia. Any text can be specified here, however only carriage return and line feed characters are recognized by the parser as end of line.
If true, the trivia produced is an elastic trivia. Elastic trivia are used to denote trivia that was not produced by parsing source text, and are usually not preserved during formatting.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.Whitespace(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a trivia with kind WhitespaceTrivia containing the specified text.
member.param: The text of the whitespace. Any text can be specified here, however only specific whitespace characters are recognized by the parser.
If true, the trivia produced is an elastic trivia. Elastic trivia are used to denote trivia that was not produced by parsing source text, and are usually not preserved during formatting.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.Comment(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a trivia with kind either SingleLineCommentTrivia or MultiLineCommentTrivia containing the specified text.
member.param: The entire text of the comment including the leading '//' token for single line comments or stop or start tokens for multiline comments.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.DisabledText(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a trivia with kind DisabledTextTrivia. Disabled text corresponds to any text between directives that is not considered active.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.PreprocessingMessage(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a trivia with kind SkipptedTextTrivia. Skipped text trivia are sometimes produced during parsing to denote invalid text that is ignored.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.Syntax.AreEquivalent(Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree,Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Determines if two trees are the same, disregarding trivia differences.
member.param: The original tree.
The new tree.

If true then the trees are equivalent if the contained nodes and tokens declaring metadata visible symbolic information are equivalent, ignoring any differences of nodes inside method bodies or initializer expressions, otherwise all nodes and tokens must be equivalent.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxToken.ContextualKind
member.summary: The kind of token, given its position in the syntax. This differs from when a contextual keyword is used in a place in the syntax that gives it its keyword meaning.
member.remarks: The ContextualKind is relevant only on contextual keyword tokens. ContextualKind differs from Kind when a token is used in context where the token should be interpreted as a keyword.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxToken.IsMissing
member.summary: Determines whether the node represents a language construct that was actually parsed from the source code. Missing nodes are generated by the parser in error scenarios to represent constructs that should have been present in the source code in order to compile successfully but were actually missing.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxToken.Text
member.summary: The text of the token as it appeared in the source.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxToken.Value
member.summary: The value designated by the token, if it is a literal (e.g. true, false, 12, "foo"). For example, the sequence of letters of an identifier, excluding the escape character if it was escaped in the source, or the characters of a string excluding the quotes and with escape sequences translated. For constants, ValueText is the canonical form of the designated value (e.g. leading zeroes are dropped).

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxToken.ValueText
member.summary: The string text of the value of the token. For example, the sequence of letters of an identifier, excluding the escape character if it was escaped in the source, or the characters of a string excluding the quotes and with escape sequences translated. For constants, ValueText is the canonical form of the designated value (e.g. leading zeroes are dropped).

If true then the trees are equivalent if the contained nodes and tokens declaring metadata visible symbolic information are equivalent, ignoring any differences of nodes inside method bodies or initializer expressions, otherwise all nodes and tokens must be equivalent.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree.WithChange(Roslyn.Compilers.IText,Roslyn.Compilers.TextChangeRange[])
member.summary: Create a new syntax tree based off this tree, the new source text and a list of changes to the old text. The changes must be a list of non-overlapping, non-abutting ranges. The list must be sorted in ascending order of the range's start positions.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree.GetChangedSpans(Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree)
member.summary: Produces a pessimistic list of spans that denote the regions of text in this tree that are changed from the text of the old tree.
member.param: The old tree.
member.remarks: The list is pessimistic because it may claim more or larger regions than actually changed.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree.GetChanges(Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree)
member.summary: Gets a list of text changes that when applied to the old tree produce this tree.
member.param: The old tree.
member.remarks: The list of changes may be different than the original changes that produced this tree.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree.GetChangeRanges(Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree)
member.summary: Gets a list of text change ranges that when applied to the old tree produce this tree.
member.param: The old tree.
member.remarks: The list of changes may be different than the original changes that produced this tree.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree.FileName
member.summary: The name of the source document file.
member.remarks:
If this syntax tree is not associated with a file, this FileName can (and often will) be the empty string.
Clients must not assume that a file exists on disk with the given name, even if a non-empty string is returned. Clients must also not assume that the values of this property are unique within a Compilation.
The FileName is used in two important ways: When debug information is emitted, this name is embedded in the debug information. When the GetLineSpan function on the SyntaxTree is called, it is used as the file name in the returned FileLinePositionSpan.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree.Text
member.summary: The text of the source document.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree.Options
member.summary: The options used by the parser to produce the syntax tree.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTree.Root
member.summary: The root node of the syntax tree.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia
member.summary: Represents "trivia" in the syntax model. Trivia represent parts of the source code that are largely insignificant to the semantic understanding of the code. Trivia includes whitespace, comments, directives, text skipped as a result of #if directives, and tokens skipped by the parser for error recovery. Trivia are always directly parents by a token. Each token may have multiple leading trivia nodes and multiple trailing trivia nodes.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.GetFullText
member.summary: Returns the complete text for the node, including leading and trailing trivia.
member.returns: The complete text for the node, including leading and trailing trivia.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.GetText
member.summary: Returns the text representation of the node, not including leading and trailing trivia.
member.returns: The test representation of the node, not including leading and trailing trivia.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.WriteTo(System.IO.TextWriter)
member.summary: Writes the full text of this token to the specified TextWriter.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.ToString
member.summary: Returns the same result as GetFullText().

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.GetStructure
member.summary: Gets the syntax node represented the structure of this trivia, if any. The HasStructure property can be used to determine if this trivia has structure.
member.returns: A SyntaxNode derived from StructuredTriviaSyntax, with the structured view of this trivia node. If this trivia node does not have structure, returns null.
member.remarks: Some types of trivia have structure that can be accessed as additional syntax nodes. These forms of trivia include: directives, where the the structure describes the structure of the directive. documentation comments, where the structure describes the XML structure of the comment. skipped tokens, where the structure describes the tokens that were skipped by the parser.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.WithAdditionalAnnotations(Roslyn.Compilers.SyntaxAnnotation[])
member.summary: Adds this annotation to a given syntax token, creating a new syntax token of the same type with the annotation on it.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.EquivalentTo(Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia)
member.summary: Determines whether this node is structurally equivalent to another.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.op_Implicit(Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia)~Roslyn.Compilers.Common.CommonSyntaxTrivia
member.summary: Converts this SyntaxTrivia to a CommonSyntaxTrivia representing the same piece of trivia.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.op_Explicit(Roslyn.Compilers.Common.CommonSyntaxTrivia)~Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia
member.summary: Converts a CommonSyntaxTrivia into a SyntaxTrivia representing the same piece of trivia.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.Token
member.summary: The parent token that this trivia is attached to, either as leading or trailing trivia.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.IsDirective
member.summary: Returns true if this trivia is a directive (#if, #region, etc.)

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.IsElastic
member.summary: Returns true if this is an "elastic trivia" node. Elastic trivia never created by the parser, but can be added to a syntax tree that was created "manually". Elastic trivia indicates location where the a formatter is free to insert additional white space.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.Kind
member.summary: Returns the kind of this trivia. The kind distinguishes between different sorts of trivia, such as spaces, newlines, comments, each sort of directive, disabled code, skipped tokens.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.FullSpan
member.summary: The absolute span of this node in characters, including its leading and trailing trivia.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.Span
member.summary: The absolute span of this node in characters, not including its leading and trailing trivia.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.FullWidth
member.summary: The complete width of the node in characters, including leading and trailing trivia.
member.remarks: The FullWidth property returns the same value as FullSpan.Length, but is somewhat more efficient.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.Width
member.summary: The width of the node in characters, not including leading and trailing trivia.
member.remarks: The Width property returns the same value as Span.Length, but is somewhat more efficient.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.HasDiagnostics
member.summary: Determines whether this node or any of its descendent nodes, tokens or trivia have any diagnostics on them.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.HasAnnotations
member.summary: Determines whether this node or any of its descendent nodes, tokens, or trivia have any annotations on them.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.CSharp.SyntaxTrivia.HasStructure
member.summary: Returns true if this trivia node has structure that is exposed through the GetStructure() method.
member.remarks: Some types of trivia have structure that can be accessed as additional syntax nodes. These forms of trivia include: directives, where the the structure describes the structure of the directive. documentation comments, where the structure describes the XML structure of the comment. skipped tokens, where the structure describes the tokens that were skipped by the parser.
